part_name: Immigration Rules Appendix Electronic Travel Authorisation

metadata.source: Immigration Rules Appendix Electronic Travel Authorisation
metadata.part: Immigration Rules Appendix Electronic Travel Authorisation
metadata.section_title: Validity requirements for an Electronic Travel Authorisation

chunks.text:
### Validity requirements for an Electronic Travel Authorisation

1.   ETA 1.1. An application for an ETA must meet the following requirements: 
    1.   (a) the application must be made in accordance with the application process on the gov.uk website using either the mobile application ‘UK ETA’ or the specified online form: ‘Apply for an ETA to come to the UK’; and
    2.   (b) the applicant must provide an email address which can be used by the Home Office to contact them; and
    3.   (c) the required fee must be paid; and
    4.   (d) the applicant must provide, in accordance with the application process, a national passport which satisfactorily establishes their identity and nationality as a national included at ETANL 1.1 Appendix ETA National List; and
    5.   (e) the applicant must provide a facial image in accordance with the application process and which complies with the rules for digital photos on ‘https://www.gov.uk/photos-for-passports’; and
    6.   (f) the applicant must be either: 
        1.   (i) seeking permission to enter the UK as a Visitor (other than a Marriage/Civil Partnership Visitor), staying in the UK for up to 6 months; or
        2.   (ii) seeking permission to enter the UK as a Creative Worker who is seeking entry to the UK pursuant to paragraph Appendix Temporary Work - Creative Worker at CRV 3.2; or
        3.   (iii) a person making a local journey from the Republic of Ireland having entered that Republic from a place outside the common travel area, or having left the UK whilst having a limited leave to enter or remain there which has since expired, who is not a S2 Healthcare Visitor.

ETA 1.2. The applicant must be a national included at ETANL 1.1. Appendix ETA National List.

ETA 1.3. An applicant who is lawfully resident in the Republic of Ireland and is travelling to the UK from elsewhere in the Common Travel Area does not need to obtain an ETA.

ETA 1.4. For the purposes of ETA 1.3, a person is lawfully resident in the Republic of Ireland if they are resident in, and entitled to reside in, the Republic of Ireland under any relevant legislation or rules which apply in the Republic of Ireland at the time of the ETA application, but a person is not lawfully resident if they may not leave or attempt to leave the Republic of Ireland without the consent of an Irish Minister.

ETA 1.5. An application which does not meet the validity requirements for an ETA application is invalid and must be rejected and not considered.

ETA 1.6. A person who is aged 16 or over who is seeking to rely on the exemption in ETA 1.3 must, if required, provide evidence to demonstrate that they are lawfully resident in the Republic of Ireland.

ETA 1.7. A person who is a British Overseas Territory Citizen or a British National (Overseas) does not require an ETA.

ETA 1.8. Subject to the conditions of VN 2.2(o) being met, a national of Jordan is permitted to travel using an ETA and arrive in the UK no later than 15:00 BST on 8 October 2024, where an ETA has been granted before 15:00 BST on 10 September 2024.

ETA 1.9. ETA Nationals who are aged 18 or under, studying at a school or educational institution in France registered with the French Ministry of Education and seeking to enter the UK as part of a school party of 5 or more pupils organised by that school or institution, do not require an ETA before they travel to the UK as a Visitor.

ETA 1.10. ETA Nationals who are aged 19 or under, studying at a school or educational institution in Germany, the existence of which is confirmed by the relevant German municipal or competent authority, and seeking to enter the UK as part of a school party of 5 or more organised by that school or institution, do not require an ETA before they travel to the UK as a Visitor.
chunks.summary: This provision applies to applicants seeking an Electronic Travel Authorization (ETA) for entry to the UK. Applicants must submit an online application, provide a valid passport, facial image, and contact details, and pay the fee. Eligibility is limited to visitors (up to 6 months), creative workers under specific categories, or those making local journeys from Ireland entering from outside the common travel area.

Eligibility is limited to visitors (up to 6 months), creative workers under specific categories, or those making local journeys from Ireland entering from outside the common travel area.

### Validity requirements for an Electronic Travel Authorisation

1.   ETA 1.1. An application for an ETA must meet the following requirements: 
    1.   (a) the application must be made in accordance with the application process on the gov.uk website using either the mobile application ‘UK ETA’ or the specified online form: ‘Apply for an ETA to come to the UK’; and
    2.   (b) the applicant must provide an email address which can be used by the Home Office to contact them; and
    3.   (c) the required fee must be paid; and
    4.   (d) the applicant must provide, in accordance with the application process, a national passport which satisfactorily establishes their identity and nationality as a national included at ETANL 1.1 Appendix ETA National List; and
    5.   (e) the applicant must provide a facial image in accordance with the application process and which complies with the rules for digital photos on ‘https://www.gov.uk/photos-for-passports’; and
    6.   (f) the applicant must be either: 
        1.   (i) seeking permission to enter the UK as a Visitor (other than a Marriage/Civil Partnership Visitor), staying in the UK for up to 6 months; or
        2.   (ii) seeking permission to enter the UK as a Creative Worker who is seeking entry to the UK pursuant to paragraph Appendix Temporary Work - Creative Worker at CRV 3.2; or
        3.   (iii) a person making a local journey from the Republic of Ireland having entered that Republic from a place outside the common travel area, or having left the UK whilst having a limited leave to enter or remain there which has since expired, who is not a S2 Healthcare Visitor.

ETA 1.2. The applicant must be a national included at ETANL 1.1. Appendix ETA National List.

ETA 1.3. An applicant who is lawfully resident in the Republic of Ireland and is travelling to the UK from elsewhere in the Common Travel Area does not need to obtain an ETA.

ETA 1.4. For the purposes of ETA 1.3, a person is lawfully resident in the Republic of Ireland if they are resident in, and entitled to reside in, the Republic of Ireland under any relevant legislation or rules which apply in the Republic of Ireland at the time of the ETA application, but a person is not lawfully resident if they may not leave or attempt to leave the Republic of Ireland without the consent of an Irish Minister.

ETA 1.5. An application which does not meet the validity requirements for an ETA application is invalid and must be rejected and not considered.

ETA 1.6. A person who is aged 16 or over who is seeking to rely on the exemption in ETA 1.3 must, if required, provide evidence to demonstrate that they are lawfully resident in the Republic of Ireland.

ETA 1.7. A person who is a British Overseas Territory Citizen or a British National (Overseas) does not require an ETA.

ETA 1.8. Subject to the conditions of VN 2.2(o) being met, a national of Jordan is permitted to travel using an ETA and arrive in the UK no later than 15:00 BST on 8 October 2024, where an ETA has been granted before 15:00 BST on 10 September 2024.

ETA 1.9. ETA Nationals who are aged 18 or under, studying at a school or educational institution in France registered with the French Ministry of Education and seeking to enter the UK as part of a school party of 5 or more pupils organised by that school or institution, do not require an ETA before they travel to the UK as a Visitor.

ETA 1.10. ETA Nationals who are aged 19 or under, studying at a school or educational institution in Germany, the existence of which is confirmed by the relevant German municipal or competent authority, and seeking to enter the UK as part of a school party of 5 or more organised by that school or institution, do not require an ETA before they travel to the UK as a Visitor.

chunks.text: ### Suitability requirements for an ETA
chunks.summary: This section applies to applicants seeking an Electronic Travel Authorization (ETA). It mandates that applicants must meet certain suitability criteria, including not posing security risks, and must not have prohibitive criminal or immigration histories; exceptions are outlined for specific circumstances.
chunks.augmented_text:
Document: Immigration Rules Appendix Electronic Travel Authorisation
Part: Immigration Rules Appendix Electronic Travel Authorisation
Section ID: Suitability requirements for an ETA
Section: Suitability requirements for an ETA
Topic: suitability

Summary: This section applies to applicants seeking an Electronic Travel Authorization (ETA). It mandates that applicants must meet certain suitability criteria, including not posing security risks, and must not have prohibitive criminal or immigration histories; exceptions are outlined for specific circumstances.

### Suitability requirements for an ETA

metadata.source: Immigration Rules Appendix Electronic Travel Authorisation
metadata.part: Immigration Rules Appendix Electronic Travel Authorisation

chunks.text:
### Exclusion or deportation order grounds

1.   ETA 2.1. An application for an ETA must be refused where: 
    1.   (a) the Secretary of State has personally directed that the applicant be excluded from the UK; or
    2.   (b) the applicant is the subject of an exclusion order; or
    3.   (c) the applicant is the subject of a deportation order, or a decision to make a deportation order.
chunks.summary: This provision applies to applicants seeking an Electronic Travel Authorization (ETA). It states that an ETA must be refused if the applicant is subject to an exclusion or deportation order or has been personally directed by the Secretary of State to be excluded, with no specified exceptions noted.
chunks.augmented_text:

Summary: This provision applies to applicants seeking an Electronic Travel Authorization (ETA). It states that an ETA must be refused if the applicant is subject to an exclusion or deportation order or has been personally directed by the Secretary of State to be excluded, with no specified exceptions noted.

### Exclusion or deportation order grounds

1.   ETA 2.1. An application for an ETA must be refused where: 
    1.   (a) the Secretary of State has personally directed that the applicant be excluded from the UK; or
    2.   (b) the applicant is the subject of an exclusion order; or
    3.   (c) the applicant is the subject of a deportation order, or a decision to make a deportation order.

metadata.source: Immigration Rules Appendix Electronic Travel Authorisation
metadata.part: Immigration Rules Appendix Electronic Travel Authorisation

chunks.text:
### Criminality grounds

1.   ETA 2.2. An application for an ETA must be refused where the applicant: 
    1.   (a) has been convicted of a criminal offence in the UK or overseas for which they have received a custodial sentence of 12 months or more; or
    2.   (b) has been convicted of a criminal offence in the UK or overseas unless more than 12 months have passed since the date of conviction.
chunks.summary: Applicants seeking an Electronic Travel Authorization (ETA) must be refused if convicted of a crime with a custodial sentence of 12 months or more, or if convicted of any crime within the past 12 months, regardless of sentence length.
chunks.augmented_text:

Summary: Applicants seeking an Electronic Travel Authorization (ETA) must be refused if convicted of a crime with a custodial sentence of 12 months or more, or if convicted of any crime within the past 12 months, regardless of sentence length.

### Criminality grounds

1.   ETA 2.2. An application for an ETA must be refused where the applicant: 
    1.   (a) has been convicted of a criminal offence in the UK or overseas for which they have received a custodial sentence of 12 months or more; or
    2.   (b) has been convicted of a criminal offence in the UK or overseas unless more than 12 months have passed since the date of conviction.

metadata.source: Immigration Rules Appendix Electronic Travel Authorisation
metadata.part: Immigration Rules Appendix Electronic Travel Authorisation

chunks.text:
### Non-conducive grounds

ETA 2.3. An application for an ETA must be refused where the applicant’s presence in the UK is not conducive to the public good because of their conduct, character, associations or other reasons (including convictions which do not fall within the criminality grounds).
chunks.summary: This provision applies to applicants seeking an Electronic Travel Authorization (ETA). It requires their application to be refused if their presence is deemed non-conducive to the public good due to conduct, character, associations, or convictions outside criminality grounds, with no explicit thresholds.

It requires their application to be refused if their presence is deemed non-conducive to the public good due to conduct, character, associations, or convictions outside criminality grounds, with no explicit thresholds.

### Non-conducive grounds

ETA 2.3. An application for an ETA must be refused where the applicant’s presence in the UK is not conducive to the public good because of their conduct, character, associations or other reasons (including convictions which do not fall within the criminality grounds).

metadata.source: Immigration Rules Appendix Electronic Travel Authorisation
metadata.part: Immigration Rules Appendix Electronic Travel Authorisation
metadata.section_title: Previous breach of immigration laws grounds

chunks.text:
### Previous breach of immigration laws grounds

1.   ETA 2.4. An application for an ETA must be refused if, when they were aged 18 or older, the applicant: 
    1.   (a) overstayed their permission, unless: 
        1.   (i) the Home Office holds a record that permission was subsequently granted with knowledge of the overstaying; or
        2.   (ii) the person left the UK voluntarily, not at the expense (directly or indirectly) of the Secretary of State, and the person overstayed for 90 days or less, where the overstaying began before 6 April 2017; or
        3.   (iii)the person left the UK voluntarily, not at the expense (directly or indirectly) of the Secretary of State, and the person overstayed for 30 days or less, where the overstaying began on or after 6 April 2017; or
        4.   (iv) the person left the UK voluntarily, not at the expense (directly or indirectly) of the Secretary of State, and the Exceptions for overstayers section of Part Suitability applies to the period of overstaying; or

    2.   (b) breached a condition attached to their permission, unless entry clearance or further permission was subsequently granted with knowledge of the breach; or
    3.   (c) was (or still is) an illegal entrant, unless the Home Office holds a record that permission was subsequently granted with knowledge of the illegal entry; or
    4.   (d) used deception in relation to an immigration application (whether or not successfully), unless the Home Office holds a record that permission was subsequently granted with knowledge of the deception.
chunks.summary: This provision applies to applicants seeking an Electronic Travel Authorization (ETA). It requires refusal if they overstayed, breached conditions, entered illegally, or used deception, unless the Home Office has a record of subsequent permission or the overstaying was voluntarily ended within specific thresholds (90 days before April 2017 or 30 days after).

It requires refusal if they overstayed, breached conditions, entered illegally, or used deception, unless the Home Office has a record of subsequent permission or the overstaying was voluntarily ended within specific thresholds (90 days before April 2017 or 30 days after).

### Previous breach of immigration laws grounds

1.   ETA 2.4. An application for an ETA must be refused if, when they were aged 18 or older, the applicant: 
    1.   (a) overstayed their permission, unless: 
        1.   (i) the Home Office holds a record that permission was subsequently granted with knowledge of the overstaying; or
        2.   (ii) the person left the UK voluntarily, not at the expense (directly or indirectly) of the Secretary of State, and the person overstayed for 90 days or less, where the overstaying began before 6 April 2017; or
        3.   (iii)the person left the UK voluntarily, not at the expense (directly or indirectly) of the Secretary of State, and the person overstayed for 30 days or less, where the overstaying began on or after 6 April 2017; or
        4.   (iv) the person left the UK voluntarily, not at the expense (directly or indirectly) of the Secretary of State, and the Exceptions for overstayers section of Part Suitability applies to the period of overstaying; or

    2.   (b) breached a condition attached to their permission, unless entry clearance or further permission was subsequently granted with knowledge of the breach; or
    3.   (c) was (or still is) an illegal entrant, unless the Home Office holds a record that permission was subsequently granted with knowledge of the illegal entry; or
    4.   (d) used deception in relation to an immigration application (whether or not successfully), unless the Home Office holds a record that permission was subsequently granted with knowledge of the deception.

metadata.source: Immigration Rules Appendix Electronic Travel Authorisation
metadata.part: Immigration Rules Appendix Electronic Travel Authorisation

chunks.text:
### False representations, etc. grounds

1.   ETA 2.5. An application for an ETA must be refused where, in relation to the current or a previous ETA application: 
    1.   (a) false representations were made, or false documents or false information was submitted (whether or not relevant to the application, and whether or not to the applicant’s knowledge); or
    2.   (b) relevant facts were not disclosed.
chunks.summary: This provision applies to applicants seeking an Electronic Travel Authorization (ETA). It requires applications to be refused if false representations, false documents, or undisclosed relevant facts are identified in current or previous ETA applications, regardless of the applicant’s knowledge, with no exceptions stated.

### False representations, etc. grounds

1.   ETA 2.5. An application for an ETA must be refused where, in relation to the current or a previous ETA application: 
    1.   (a) false representations were made, or false documents or false information was submitted (whether or not relevant to the application, and whether or not to the applicant’s knowledge); or
    2.   (b) relevant facts were not disclosed.

chunks.text:
### Debt to the NHS grounds

ETA 2.6. DELETED
chunks.summary: This provision applies to visa applicants subject to the NHS debt grounds. Applicants must not owe an unresolved NHS surcharge debt exceeding the set threshold to be granted entry clearance; exceptions or updated thresholds are unspecified.

### Debt to the NHS grounds

ETA 2.6. DELETED

metadata.source: Immigration Rules Appendix Electronic Travel Authorisation
metadata.part: Immigration Rules Appendix Electronic Travel Authorisation

chunks.text:
### Unpaid litigation costs grounds

ETA 2.7. An application for an ETA must be refused where the applicant has failed to pay litigation costs awarded to the Home Office.
chunks.summary: This provision applies to ETA applicants. If an applicant has unpaid litigation costs awarded to the Home Office, their ETA application must be refused. There are no exceptions specified.
chunks.augmented_text:
Document: Immigration Rules Appendix Electronic Travel Authorisation

Section: Unpaid litigation costs grounds
Topic: eligibility

Summary: This provision applies to ETA applicants. If an applicant has unpaid litigation costs awarded to the Home Office, their ETA application must be refused. There are no exceptions specified.

### Unpaid litigation costs grounds

ETA 2.7. An application for an ETA must be refused where the applicant has failed to pay litigation costs awarded to the Home Office.

metadata.source: Immigration Rules Appendix Electronic Travel Authorisation
metadata.part: Immigration Rules Appendix Electronic Travel Authorisation

chunks.text:
### Previous cancellation of an ETA

ETA 2.8. An application for an ETA must be refused if the applicant had an ETA cancelled by the Home Office under ETA 5.8, unless the Home Office holds a record that entry clearance, or permission to enter or stay was subsequently granted with knowledge of the cancellation.
chunks.summary: Applicants must be refused an ETA if their previous ETA was cancelled by the Home Office under ETA 5.8, unless there is a record showing they were granted entry clearance or permission with knowledge of the cancellation.
chunks.augmented_text:

Topic: leave-to-enter

Summary: Applicants must be refused an ETA if their previous ETA was cancelled by the Home Office under ETA 5.8, unless there is a record showing they were granted entry clearance or permission with knowledge of the cancellation.

### Previous cancellation of an ETA

ETA 2.8. An application for an ETA must be refused if the applicant had an ETA cancelled by the Home Office under ETA 5.8, unless the Home Office holds a record that entry clearance, or permission to enter or stay was subsequently granted with knowledge of the cancellation.

metadata.source: Immigration Rules Appendix Electronic Travel Authorisation
metadata.part: Immigration Rules Appendix Electronic Travel Authorisation

chunks.text:
### Previous refusal as a Visitor

1.   ETA 2.9. An application for an ETA must be refused if the applicant has previously been refused entry clearance, permission to enter or permission to stay under Appendix V: Visitor, unless the Home Office holds a record that either: 
    1.   (a) a valid ETA, entry clearance or permission to enter or stay was held and was not cancelled as a result of that refusal; or
    2.   (b) a valid ETA, entry clearance, or permission to enter or stay was subsequently granted with knowledge of that refusal.
chunks.summary: Applicants for an Electronic Travel Authorization (ETA) who were previously refused entry or stay under Appendix V: Visitor must generally be refused unless the Home Office holds records of a valid, un-canceled ETA or permission, or if such permission was granted with knowledge of the earlier refusal.
chunks.augmented_text:
Document: Immigration Rules Appendix Electronic Travel Authorisation

Section: Previous refusal as a Visitor
Topic: suitability

Summary: Applicants for an Electronic Travel Authorization (ETA) who were previously refused entry or stay under Appendix V: Visitor must generally be refused unless the Home Office holds records of a valid, un-canceled ETA or permission, or if such permission was granted with knowledge of the earlier refusal.

### Previous refusal as a Visitor

1.   ETA 2.9. An application for an ETA must be refused if the applicant has previously been refused entry clearance, permission to enter or permission to stay under Appendix V: Visitor, unless the Home Office holds a record that either: 
    1.   (a) a valid ETA, entry clearance or permission to enter or stay was held and was not cancelled as a result of that refusal; or
    2.   (b) a valid ETA, entry clearance, or permission to enter or stay was subsequently granted with knowledge of that refusal.

metadata.source: Immigration Rules Appendix Electronic Travel Authorisation
metadata.part: Immigration Rules Appendix Electronic Travel Authorisation

chunks.text:
### Decision on an ETA application

ETA 3.1. If the Secretary of State is satisfied the validity requirements are met and the application is not refused on suitability grounds the applicant will be granted an ETA; otherwise, the application for an ETA will be refused.
chunks.summary: This provision applies to ETA applicants, specifying that they will be granted approval if their application meets validity requirements and poses no suitability concerns; otherwise, it will be refused.
chunks.augmented_text:
Document: Immigration Rules Appendix Electronic Travel Authorisation

Section ID: ETA 3.1
Section: Decision on an ETA application
Topic: suitability

Summary: This provision applies to ETA applicants, specifying that they will be granted approval if their application meets validity requirements and poses no suitability concerns; otherwise, it will be refused.

### Decision on an ETA application

ETA 3.1. If the Secretary of State is satisfied the validity requirements are met and the application is not refused on suitability grounds the applicant will be granted an ETA; otherwise, the application for an ETA will be refused.

metadata.source: Immigration Rules Appendix Electronic Travel Authorisation
metadata.part: Immigration Rules Appendix Electronic Travel Authorisation
metadata.section_title: Period of grant of an ETA

chunks.text:
### Period of grant of an ETA

ETA 4.1. An ETA will be valid for 2 years from the date of grant or until the expiry of the holder’s passport used in the ETA application, whichever is sooner.

1.   ETA 4.2. A person holding a valid ETA may make multiple journeys to the UK, for the purpose of seeking permission to enter on arrival as either: 
    1.   (a) a Visitor, seeking entry for up to 6 months on each occasion; or
    2.   (b) a Creative Worker who is seeking entry to the UK pursuant to Appendix Temporary Work – Creative Worker at CRV 3.2.

ETA 4.3. An ETA will be valid and confer permission to travel only where the holder travels using the passport specified in the ETA application.
chunks.summary: An ETA applicant is granted a 2-year validity or until their passport expires, whichever occurs first. Holders can make multiple UK visits as a Visitor (up to 6 months per trip) or as a Creative Worker, using the specified passport. Travel validity requires using the passport named in the ETA application.

### Period of grant of an ETA

ETA 4.1. An ETA will be valid for 2 years from the date of grant or until the expiry of the holder’s passport used in the ETA application, whichever is sooner.

1.   ETA 4.2. A person holding a valid ETA may make multiple journeys to the UK, for the purpose of seeking permission to enter on arrival as either: 
    1.   (a) a Visitor, seeking entry for up to 6 months on each occasion; or
    2.   (b) a Creative Worker who is seeking entry to the UK pursuant to Appendix Temporary Work – Creative Worker at CRV 3.2.

ETA 4.3. An ETA will be valid and confer permission to travel only where the holder travels using the passport specified in the ETA application.

metadata.source: Immigration Rules Appendix Electronic Travel Authorisation
metadata.part: Immigration Rules Appendix Electronic Travel Authorisation

chunks.text: ### Cancellation of an ETA
chunks.summary: This provision applies to travelers holding an Electronic Travel Authorisation (ETA). It stipulates that an ETA can be cancelled if conditions such as non-compliance or security concerns arise, with exceptions only under specific circumstances. Applicants must adhere to the rules to maintain their ETA validity.
chunks.augmented_text:
Document: Immigration Rules Appendix Electronic Travel Authorisation

Section ID: SW 3.1
Section: Cancellation of an ETA
Topic: procedures

Summary: This provision applies to travelers holding an Electronic Travel Authorisation (ETA). It stipulates that an ETA can be cancelled if conditions such as non-compliance or security concerns arise, with exceptions only under specific circumstances. Applicants must adhere to the rules to maintain their ETA validity.

### Cancellation of an ETA

metadata.source: Immigration Rules Appendix Electronic Travel Authorisation
metadata.part: Immigration Rules Appendix Electronic Travel Authorisation
metadata.section_title: Cancellation on exclusion or deportation order grounds

chunks.text:
### Cancellation on exclusion or deportation order grounds

1.   ETA 5.1. An ETA held by a person must be cancelled where: 
    1.   (a) the Secretary of State has personally directed that the applicant be excluded from the UK; or
    2.   (b) the applicant is the subject of an exclusion order; or
    3.   (c) the applicant is the subject of a deportation order, or a decision to make a deportation order.
chunks.summary: This provision applies to individuals with an Electronic Travel Authorization (ETA) who are subject to exclusion or deportation orders. It mandates cancellation of the ETA if the Secretary of State directs exclusion, or if the person is under an exclusion or deportation order or decision, with no exceptions stated.
chunks.augmented_text:

Topic: suitability

Summary: This provision applies to individuals with an Electronic Travel Authorization (ETA) who are subject to exclusion or deportation orders. It mandates cancellation of the ETA if the Secretary of State directs exclusion, or if the person is under an exclusion or deportation order or decision, with no exceptions stated.

### Cancellation on exclusion or deportation order grounds

1.   ETA 5.1. An ETA held by a person must be cancelled where: 
    1.   (a) the Secretary of State has personally directed that the applicant be excluded from the UK; or
    2.   (b) the applicant is the subject of an exclusion order; or
    3.   (c) the applicant is the subject of a deportation order, or a decision to make a deportation order.

metadata.source: Immigration Rules Appendix Electronic Travel Authorisation
metadata.part: Immigration Rules Appendix Electronic Travel Authorisation

chunks.text:
### Cancellation on criminality grounds

1.   ETA 5.2. An ETA held by a person must be cancelled where the person: 
    1.   (a) has been convicted of a criminal offence in the UK or overseas for which they have received a custodial sentence of 12 months or more; or
    2.   (b) has been convicted of a criminal offence in the UK or overseas unless more than 12 months has passed since the date of conviction
chunks.summary: This provision applies to individuals holding an Electronic Travel Authorization (ETA). It mandates the cancellation of an ETA if the holder has a custodial sentence of 12 months or more, or has been convicted of certain offences within the past 12 months, regardless of the sentence length.

Topic: criminality

Summary: This provision applies to individuals holding an Electronic Travel Authorization (ETA). It mandates the cancellation of an ETA if the holder has a custodial sentence of 12 months or more, or has been convicted of certain offences within the past 12 months, regardless of the sentence length.

### Cancellation on criminality grounds

1.   ETA 5.2. An ETA held by a person must be cancelled where the person: 
    1.   (a) has been convicted of a criminal offence in the UK or overseas for which they have received a custodial sentence of 12 months or more; or
    2.   (b) has been convicted of a criminal offence in the UK or overseas unless more than 12 months has passed since the date of conviction

metadata.source: Immigration Rules Appendix Electronic Travel Authorisation
metadata.part: Immigration Rules Appendix Electronic Travel Authorisation

chunks.text:
### Cancellation on non-conducive grounds

ETA 5.3. An ETA held by a person must be cancelled where the person’s presence in the UK is not conducive to the public good because of their conduct, character, associations or other reasons (including convictions which do not fall within the criminality grounds).
chunks.summary: This provision applies to individuals holding an Electronic Travel Authorization (ETA). It requires cancellation if their presence is deemed non-conducive to the public good due to conduct, character, associations, or convictions, including non-criminal conduct; no specific thresholds are specified.
chunks.augmented_text:
Document: Immigration Rules Appendix Electronic Travel Authorisation
Part: Immigration Rules Appendix Electronic Travel Authorisation
Section ID: ETA 5.3
Section: Cancellation on non-conducive grounds
Topic: grounds

Summary: This provision applies to individuals holding an Electronic Travel Authorization (ETA). It requires cancellation if their presence is deemed non-conducive to the public good due to conduct, character, associations, or convictions, including non-criminal conduct; no specific thresholds are specified.

### Cancellation on non-conducive grounds

ETA 5.3. An ETA held by a person must be cancelled where the person’s presence in the UK is not conducive to the public good because of their conduct, character, associations or other reasons (including convictions which do not fall within the criminality grounds).

metadata.source: Immigration Rules Appendix Electronic Travel Authorisation
metadata.part: Immigration Rules Appendix Electronic Travel Authorisation
metadata.section_title: Cancellation on breach of immigration laws grounds

chunks.text:
### Cancellation on breach of immigration laws grounds

1.   ETA 5.4. An ETA held by a person must be cancelled if, when they were aged 18 or older, the holder: 
    1.   (a) overstayed their permission, unless; 
        1.   (i) the Home Office holds a record that permission was subsequently granted with knowledge of the overstaying; or
        2.   (ii) the person left the UK voluntarily, not at the expense (directly indirectly) of the Secretary of State, and the person overstayed for 90 days or less, where the overstaying began before 6 April 2017; or
        3.   (iii)the person left the UK voluntarily, not at the expense (directly or indirectly) of the Secretary of State, and the person overstayed for 30 days or less, where the overstaying began on or after 6 April 2017; or
        4.   (iv) the person left the UK voluntarily, not at the expense (directly or indirectly) of the Secretary of State, and the Exceptions for overstayers section of Part Suitability applies to the period of overstaying; or

    2.   (b) breached a condition attached to their permission, unless entry clearance or further permission was subsequently granted with knowledge of the breach; or
    3.   (c) was (or still is) an illegal entrant, unless the Home Office holds a record that permission was subsequently granted with knowledge of the illegal entry; or
    4.   (d) used deception in relation to an immigration application (whether or not successfully), unless the Home Office holds a record that permission was subsequently granted with knowledge of the deception.
chunks.summary: This provision applies to ETA holders aged 18 or over and outlines grounds for their cancellation, including overstaying, breaching conditions, illegal entry, or use of deception. Cancellation is mandatory unless the individual left voluntarily under specific conditions, or permission was granted with knowledge of the breach or overstaying; exceptions depend on time thresholds and prior record checks.

Cancellation is mandatory unless the individual left voluntarily under specific conditions, or permission was granted with knowledge of the breach or overstaying; exceptions depend on time thresholds and prior record checks.

### Cancellation on breach of immigration laws grounds

1.   ETA 5.4. An ETA held by a person must be cancelled if, when they were aged 18 or older, the holder: 
    1.   (a) overstayed their permission, unless; 
        1.   (i) the Home Office holds a record that permission was subsequently granted with knowledge of the overstaying; or
        2.   (ii) the person left the UK voluntarily, not at the expense (directly indirectly) of the Secretary of State, and the person overstayed for 90 days or less, where the overstaying began before 6 April 2017; or

    3.   (c) was (or still is) an illegal entrant, unless the Home Office holds a record that permission was subsequently granted with knowledge of the illegal entry; or
    4.   (d) used deception in relation to an immigration application (whether or not successfully), unless the Home Office holds a record that permission was subsequently granted with knowledge of the deception.

metadata.source: Immigration Rules Appendix Electronic Travel Authorisation
metadata.part: Immigration Rules Appendix Electronic Travel Authorisation
metadata.section_title: Cancellation on false representations, etc. grounds

chunks.text:
### Cancellation on false representations, etc. grounds

1.   ETA 5.5. An ETA held by a person must be cancelled where in relation to an ETA application: 
    1.   (a) false representations were made, or false documents or false information submitted (whether or not relevant to the application, and whether or not to the applicant’s knowledge); or
    2.   (b) relevant facts were not disclosed.
chunks.summary: This provision applies to travelers holding an Electronic Travel Authorization (ETA). It mandates cancellation if false representations, false documents, or failure to disclose relevant facts are found in their application, regardless of the applicant’s knowledge. There are no exceptions specified.

There are no exceptions specified.

### Cancellation on false representations, etc. grounds

1.   ETA 5.5. An ETA held by a person must be cancelled where in relation to an ETA application: 
    1.   (a) false representations were made, or false documents or false information submitted (whether or not relevant to the application, and whether or not to the applicant’s knowledge); or
    2.   (b) relevant facts were not disclosed.

metadata.source: Immigration Rules Appendix Electronic Travel Authorisation
metadata.part: Immigration Rules Appendix Electronic Travel Authorisation
metadata.section_title: Cancellation due to debt to the NHS

chunks.text:
### Cancellation due to debt to the NHS

ETA 5.6. An ETA held by a person must be cancelled where a relevant NHS body has notified the Secretary of State that the holder has failed to pay charges under relevant NHS regulations on charges to overseas visitors and the outstanding charges have a total value of at least £500.
chunks.summary: This provision applies to ETA holders who owe NHS charges. It requires the cancellation of their ETA if a relevant NHS body notifies the Secretary of State that they owe at least £500 in unpaid NHS charges. Cancellation occurs automatically upon notification of the debt.

Section: Cancellation due to debt to the NHS
Topic: financial

Summary: This provision applies to ETA holders who owe NHS charges. It requires the cancellation of their ETA if a relevant NHS body notifies the Secretary of State that they owe at least £500 in unpaid NHS charges. Cancellation occurs automatically upon notification of the debt.

### Cancellation due to debt to the NHS

ETA 5.6. An ETA held by a person must be cancelled where a relevant NHS body has notified the Secretary of State that the holder has failed to pay charges under relevant NHS regulations on charges to overseas visitors and the outstanding charges have a total value of at least £500.

metadata.source: Immigration Rules Appendix Electronic Travel Authorisation
metadata.part: Immigration Rules Appendix Electronic Travel Authorisation
metadata.section_title: Cancellation due to unpaid litigation costs

chunks.text:
### Cancellation due to unpaid litigation costs

ETA 5.7. An ETA held by a person must be cancelled where the holder has failed to pay litigation costs awarded to the Home Office.
chunks.summary: This provision applies to ETA holders and mandates cancellation if they fail to pay litigation costs awarded to the Home Office. The key condition is non-payment of such costs, which leads to automatic cancellation; no exceptions are specified.
chunks.augmented_text:

Topic: administration

### Cancellation due to unpaid litigation costs

ETA 5.7. An ETA held by a person must be cancelled where the holder has failed to pay litigation costs awarded to the Home Office.

metadata.source: Immigration Rules Appendix Electronic Travel Authorisation
metadata.part: Immigration Rules Appendix Electronic Travel Authorisation
metadata.section_title: Cancellation of an ETA where validity requirements are not met

chunks.text:
### Cancellation of an ETA where validity requirements are not met

ETA 5.8. An ETA held by a person may be cancelled where it has been issued and one or more of the requirements of ETA 1.1. and ETA 1.2. were not met either at the time of the application or subsequently.

Print this page
chunks.summary: This provision applies to individuals holding an Electronic Travel Authorization (ETA). It states that an ETA can be canceled if any validity requirements, specified in ETA 1.1. and ETA 1.2., were unmet at application or later. No specific exceptions are outlined; compliance with the requirements is mandatory for validity.

### Cancellation of an ETA where validity requirements are not met

ETA 5.8. An ETA held by a person may be cancelled where it has been issued and one or more of the requirements of ETA 1.1. and ETA 1.2. were not met either at the time of the application or subsequently.
